snippet.textDisplay: I have one although from a different company. I had one before but it died after a long and very useful life. I have two extension rings now, which means I can do bigger things (baking cakes for one) in it. If you're on your own it's a good-sized little oven - which doesn't need long to preheat. You do have to be careful when removing things though (especially if you don't remove the extension ring first.....) as the faint scars on the inside of both forearms proves :) I have never regretted buying mine
snippet.textOriginal: I have one although from a different company. I had one before but it died after a long and very useful life. I have two extension rings now, which means I can do bigger things (baking cakes for one) in it. If you're on your own it's a good-sized little oven - which doesn't need long to preheat. You do have to be careful when removing things though (especially if you don't remove the extension ring first.....) as the faint scars on the inside of both forearms proves :) I have never regretted buying mine

snippet.textDisplay:
air fryer is a misnomer - it's a (small) convection oven with better air circulation. If for some crazy reason I didn't have an oven, but could have an air fryer or something about that size, I'd just get a large-ish toaster oven instead. A toaster oven has far more versatility, and will be significantly cheaper (are toaster ovens not a thing in the UK?).
Final comment: not only will an "air fryer" never replace frying something in oil, food cooked in an air fryer will never come close to food fried in oil.
snippet.textOriginal:
air fryer is a misnomer - it's a (small) convection oven with better air circulation. If for some crazy reason I didn't have an oven, but could have an air fryer or something about that size, I'd just get a large-ish toaster oven instead. A toaster oven has far more versatility, and will be significantly cheaper (are toaster ovens not a thing in the UK?).
Final comment: not only will an "air fryer" never replace frying something in oil, food cooked in an air fryer will never come close to food fried in oil.

snippet.textDisplay:
We've got one and we refer to it as a hallogen oven rather than a fryer. A few ideas though, roast chicken, season and prepare as usual, put in breast side down for 25 mins on max, then flip and leave to cook at about 220 for 45-50 mins.

Second roast chipatoes, dice potato into cubes no smaller than 1cm. Get a food bag and add the cubed potatoes. Add seasoning and oil to the bag and twist the opening to trap the air inside and shake to coat potatoes. Pour out the potatoes onto cooking surface and cook at about 230 for 30-40 mins. (Named roast chipatoes because they're about the dimensions of a diced large chip and roasted like a roast potato)

Temps and times approximate going from memory.
snippet.textOriginal:
We've got one and we refer to it as a hallogen oven rather than a fryer. A few ideas though, roast chicken, season and prepare as usual, put in breast side down for 25 mins on max, then flip and leave to cook at about 220 for 45-50 mins.

Second roast chipatoes, dice potato into cubes no smaller than 1cm. Get a food bag and add the cubed potatoes. Add seasoning and oil to the bag and twist the opening to trap the air inside and shake to coat potatoes. Pour out the potatoes onto cooking surface and cook at about 230 for 30-40 mins. (Named roast chipatoes because they're about the dimensions of a diced large chip and roasted like a roast potato)

Temps and times approximate going from memory.

snippet.textDisplay: The name is definitely a misnomer. 'Air Fryers' are best for frozen foods - heating them to a crunchy finish without needing to sit around for 30 minutes while your oven pre-heats. It's easy to say 'cooked in the same amount of time', while glossing over the two minute prep time those 'fryers' take.
snippet.textOriginal: The name is definitely a misnomer. 'Air Fryers' are best for frozen foods - heating them to a crunchy finish without needing to sit around for 30 minutes while your oven pre-heats. It's easy to say 'cooked in the same amount of time', while glossing over the two minute prep time those 'fryers' take.

snippet.textDisplay: So it makes great sausages and it's a great steamer. With the chips, it roasts them more than it does make chips. So as long as the food being baked has a high amount of fat like the sausages and the fat parts of the steak, it heats the fat and the fat cooks the meat. So it's great for sausages, great for steaming foods like vegetables and fish and it's good for toasting breading on the outside of things. As for the doughnuts, it looks like it made sweet baked rolls instead of actually making doughnuts. So all in all, it's good for steaming and browning some things and baking other things.
snippet.textOriginal: So it makes great sausages and it's a great steamer. With the chips, it roasts them more than it does make chips. So as long as the food being baked has a high amount of fat like the sausages and the fat parts of the steak, it heats the fat and the fat cooks the meat. So it's great for sausages, great for steaming foods like vegetables and fish and it's good for toasting breading on the outside of things. As for the doughnuts, it looks like it made sweet baked rolls instead of actually making doughnuts. So all in all, it's good for steaming and browning some things and baking other things.

snippet.textDisplay: this sort of thing sells to people who are terrified of the basic equipment -- oven, microwave and a saucepan -- that can be used to cook anything. the fact it replicates a hot oven more than a fryer is the demonstration that people have oven terror but are predisposed to "solve" their problems with a magic appliance. the target market is probably asian cultures where they never use ovens, if they even own them. the other culprit is parents who don't involve their children in cooking, who then imagine mum must be doing something terribly clever and adulty with the oven when she makes a roast. i have met loads of adult people who desperately need the simple lesson that you turn on an oven, it gets hot, and when you stick food in it gets cooked with a very wide margin for error. this also sells to young people who are still too stupid to be horrified by the prospect of cluttering their kitchen with large appliances that they rarely use and that nearly always overlap in function with other equipment. if you renovate your kitchen with huge benches, you can park it right next to the electric pie maker, electric pizza cooker, electric muffin cooker, electric rice cooker, electric hot-dogger, your thermothingy, your waffle iron, your god damned omelette maker that saves you the effort of folding the thing in half, and ten different assorted steamers. and it's all shit to clean. but i never met a substance i couldn't remove from a simple stainless steel pan in seconds with boiling caustic soda (use eye protection. don't show this to your kids)
snippet.textOriginal: this sort of thing sells to people who are terrified of the basic equipment -- oven, microwave and a saucepan -- that can be used to cook anything. the fact it replicates a hot oven more than a fryer is the demonstration that people have oven terror but are predisposed to "solve" their problems with a magic appliance. the target market is probably asian cultures where they never use ovens, if they even own them. the other culprit is parents who don't involve their children in cooking, who then imagine mum must be doing something terribly clever and adulty with the oven when she makes a roast. i have met loads of adult people who desperately need the simple lesson that you turn on an oven, it gets hot, and when you stick food in it gets cooked with a very wide margin for error. this also sells to young people who are still too stupid to be horrified by the prospect of cluttering their kitchen with large appliances that they rarely use and that nearly always overlap in function with other equipment. if you renovate your kitchen with huge benches, you can park it right next to the electric pie maker, electric pizza cooker, electric muffin cooker, electric rice cooker, electric hot-dogger, your thermothingy, your waffle iron, your god damned omelette maker that saves you the effort of folding the thing in half, and ten different assorted steamers. and it's all shit to clean. but i never met a substance i couldn't remove from a simple stainless steel pan in seconds with boiling caustic soda (use eye protection. don't show this to your kids)

snippet.textDisplay:
While it certainly has its uses as a multitasker, as far as the category of countertop cooking appliance goes, I would be interested in knowing how its utility compares to a comparably-priced countertop electric induction cooking hob when paired with some inexpensive pots/pans.

If one is living in a situation with limited counter space or no included cooking appliances (university dorms, for instance), would Sorted consider a product like this to be worth the investment over a countertop hob? (Considering cleaning, storage, utility, ease of use, quality of results, safety, etc.) I’m not currently in a situation of that sort, just curious.
snippet.textOriginal:
While it certainly has its uses as a multitasker, as far as the category of countertop cooking appliance goes, I would be interested in knowing how its utility compares to a comparably-priced countertop electric induction cooking hob when paired with some inexpensive pots/pans. 

If one is living in a situation with limited counter space or no included cooking appliances (university dorms, for instance), would Sorted consider a product like this to be worth the investment over a countertop hob? snippet.textDisplay:
When these things first appeared (in this form) they were marketed as 'halogen ovens', the air fryer is a change in marketing to appeal to the healthier eating crowd. My mum has had one of these for about 10 years now and she loves it. She lives on her own and so is usually cooking for one, and this is quicker and easier for her than the oven.

It's great for sausages and chicken, it's also great for warming things up (reheated pizza works a treat in this).

They're not for everyone and of course a chef is going to achieve far more with a proper oven and hob, but you're definitely not the target market for this thing. They're far from perfect of course, but my mum gets a lot of use from hers.
snippet.textOriginal:
When these things first appeared (in this form) they were marketed as 'halogen ovens', the air fryer is a change in marketing to appeal to the healthier eating crowd.  My mum has had one of these for about 10 years now and she loves it. She lives on her own and so is usually cooking for one, and this is quicker and easier for her than the oven.

It's great for sausages and chicken, it's also great for warming things up (reheated pizza works a treat in this).

They're not for everyone and of course a chef is going to achieve far more with a proper oven and hob, but you're definitely not the target market for this thing. They're far from perfect of course, but my mum gets a lot of use from hers.

snippet.textDisplay: The problem with Ben’s argument of what they’re testing is air fryers are not marketed to individuals as alternative kitchen appliances. They’re marketed as alternative cooking methods via unique appliance in order to create supposedly healthier copycat versions of favorite dishes. James is correct that it cooks the food but it wouldn’t qualify as the best version. You would not whip this out for a dinner party unless it were a group of particularly health conscious, trend obsessed friends.
snippet.textOriginal: The problem with Ben’s argument of what they’re testing is air fryers are not marketed to individuals as alternative kitchen appliances. snippet.textOriginal: So really it's just a small, strong oven.

snippet.textDisplay: I have one of these, and I use it a LOT.  But almost exclusively as a replacement as an oven, rather than as a fryer.  I live in a fairly warm climate, and I love the fact that I can load it up in the kitchen, then take it out on the patio to run, so I get baked food without heating up my home by using the oven.  There are some things that a standard oven does better, but for cooking small amounts of something, for baking without heating up the house, or when I need to bake at two different temperatures (One in the standard oven, one in the counter-top) it's hard to beat.
snippet.textOriginal: I have one of these, and I use it a LOT.  But almost exclusively as a replacement as an oven, rather than as a fryer.  I live in a fairly warm climate, and I love the fact that I can load it up in the kitchen, then take it out on the patio to run, so I get baked food without heating up my home by using the oven.  There are some things that a standard oven does better, but for cooking small amounts of something, for baking without heating up the house, or when I need to bake at two different temperatures (One in the standard oven, one in the counter-top) it's hard to beat.

snippet.textDisplay: Halogen ovens have been around for years. I'm onto my second because they are energy saving because of the size. You want a Crust? Oil steaks and season with salt. Place them in a preheated baking tray. Or preheat element at max for 3 minutes , and grill at max on high shelf. It will for Your Breaded items were cooked too cool. Similar haddock chunky breaded portions take 25 minutes in a 1200w at 180 degrees centigrade on a high shelf. Wash function? Less good for the element. I'd just wash in the sink. Yes; there are better models. Flavorwave brand 1500w does the trick.
snippet.textOriginal: Halogen ovens have been around for years. I'm onto my second because they are energy saving because of the size. You want a Crust? Oil steaks and season with salt. Place them in a preheated baking tray. Or preheat element at max for 3 minutes , and grill at max on high shelf. It will for Your Breaded items were cooked too cool. Similar haddock chunky breaded portions take 25 minutes in a 1200w at 180 degrees centigrade on a high shelf. Wash function? Less good for the element. I'd just wash in the sink. Yes; there are better models. Flavorwave brand 1500w does the trick.

snippet.textDisplay: I use my air fryer for potato wedges (see how I avoided the "fires" vs "chips" discussion?) all the time (just last night, for example).  Using Fahrenheit, for best results, cook at 420 degrees F for 20 minutes ("Four twenty for twenty" is how to remember it.)  In Celsius that would be about 415 degrees but you still need 20 minutes.  Preheating doesn't change the outcome much.
snippet.textOriginal: I use my air fryer for potato wedges (see how I avoided the "fires" vs "chips" discussion?) all the time (just last night, for example). snippet.textDisplay: It's a giant, overpriced, "EZ Bake Oven". If you're buying something like this to eat a bit healthier, then I say go for it. You could definitely do worse on ways to improve what you eat. But if you're buying it for ease of use, speed, convenience, or because it's "better" than other cooking methods...... then it's a no from me. Because it's just none of those things.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think you probably should have cut the holes in the donuts because that changes the ratio of volume to surface area and they would cook more evenly, with thinner crust and less ballooning in the center. I wonder whether a recipe for the style of fasnacht using baking powder instead of yeast would work better; those don't rise as much and have a cake-like texture that lends itself to baking with reasonable success when you don't want to fry.

In the US, some full-size ovens, in kitchen ranges or stand-alone, are advertised with an "air-fryer" mode and my thought was, "how is that different from a normal convection oven?", home versions of which have been common for more than a decade. I suppose you need a supporting rack with tighter spacing, but you could use any number of things that you might have in the kitchen already.
snippet.textOriginal:
I think you probably should have cut the holes in the donuts because that changes the ratio of volume to surface area and they would cook more evenly, with thinner crust and less ballooning in the center. I wonder whether a recipe for the style of fasnacht using baking powder instead of yeast would work better; those don't rise as much and have a cake-like texture that lends itself to baking with reasonable success when you don't want to fry.

In the US, some full-size ovens, in kitchen ranges or stand-alone, are advertised with an "air-fryer" mode and my thought was, "how is that different from a normal convection oven?", home versions of which have been common for more than a decade. I suppose you need a supporting rack with tighter spacing, but you could use any number of things that you might have in the kitchen already.

snippet.textDisplay: I have one of these and like it very much for certain things, especially chicken and sausage with veg underneath catching the drippings. There are good reasons for some people to use these, and if you'd focused on those instead of how much "better" food comes out of a full oven or deep fryer your review would have been more useful. Even better would be a comparison of the glass halogen oven with a basketed air fryer, the newish air fryer/convection toaster oven, and multi-use Ninja Foodi or Instant Pot with a/f lid. A challenge with each mate turning out something good from one of these would be interesting and fun.
snippet.textOriginal: I have one of these and like it very much for certain things, especially chicken and sausage with veg underneath catching the drippings. There are good reasons for some people to use these, and if you'd focused on those instead of how much "better" food comes out of a full oven or deep fryer your review would have been more useful. Even better would be a comparison of the glass halogen oven with a basketed air fryer, the newish air fryer/convection toaster oven, and multi-use Ninja Foodi or Instant Pot with a/f lid. snippet.textDisplay: We have had this in our homes for years and years and recommended it to everyone! We use it to make crispy potatoes and baked chicken. We also use it to bake breads in the morning so we do not have to heat up an oven. Just throw em in there and have baked breads in less than 10 minutes. We also use it for pizza, especially heating up leftover pizza. It is literally amazing for all kinds of stuff! It is a healthier option of baking a lot of stuff that would otherwise get drowned in oils or butter in a pan.

snippet.textDisplay: I bought one a couple years ago ... used it for maybe 50 hours in total and the halogen bulb burnt out... as it's difficult to buy replacement bulbs, you basically have to buy another...  Also, it's not really easy to clean it... especially if you cook chicken or steaks... all the grease collects at the bottom.
snippet.textOriginal: I bought one a couple years ago ... used it for maybe 50 hours in total and the halogen bulb burnt out... as it's difficult to buy replacement bulbs, you basically have to buy another...  Also, it's not really easy to clean it... especially if you cook chicken or steaks... all the grease collects at the bottom.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hey guys, recently I made my own ramen and cheated using modcons as much as possible. I followed Ramen_Lord's recipe for pressure cooker tonkotsu and a recipe for 36-hour sous vide chashu. It turned out to taste way better than I expected. Since I know you have a pressure cooker and an immersion circulator I think it'd be pretty cool for you to try it out. Currently the recipe is famous on Reddit but not really known anywhere else, it'd be good to showcase it a bit.
Also the recipe includes instructions for making your own low-hydration noodles, which is apparently extremely difficult and not worth it, so it's perfect as a challenge for one of the chefs. Maybe Jamie could do the chashu, Barry could do the pork broth, Mike could do the nitamago, James can do the tare and Ben can do the noodles? I think it'd be a fun video.
snippet.textOriginal:
Hey guys, recently I made my own ramen and cheated using modcons as much as possible. I followed Ramen_Lord's recipe for pressure cooker tonkotsu and a recipe for 36-hour sous vide chashu. It turned out to taste way better than I expected. Since I know you have a pressure cooker and an immersion circulator I think it'd be pretty cool for you to try it out. Currently the recipe is famous on Reddit but not really known anywhere else, it'd be good to showcase it a bit.
Also the recipe includes instructions for making your own low-hydration noodles, which is apparently extremely difficult and not worth it, so it's perfect as a challenge for one of the chefs. Maybe Jamie could do the chashu, Barry could do the pork broth, Mike could do the nitamago, James can do the tare and Ben can do the noodles? I think it'd be a fun video.

snippet.textDisplay:
Ben: "Its even got a Thor function..." ha ha ha ha ha roflmao! - with visions of lightning going off inside the oven.

Now, I have one of these and I find it very useful. It bakes quite well. As for steak? Cook it from frozen, bring it as close as you want to the halogen head, sear it to your liking, test for doneness and drop the temp and/or distance if need be.

The gill-like features (air-frying) like with any broiler, is all about time, temperature, and distance. The convection feature only helps to keep even temperature throughout the oven, which is great for baking stuff.

Roast Chicken, duck, meats, tandoori, preheat a metal plate and try making flat bread. Casseroles, Mac& Cheese; pies, pasties, sausage rolls, pirozhki, ... grill some cheesesteak on a metal plate? Options are endless!

The gill-like features (air-frying) like with any broiler, is all about time, temperature, and distance. The convection feature only helps to keep even temperature throughout the oven, which is great for baking stuff.

Roast Chicken, duck, meats, tandoori, preheat a metal plate and try making flat bread. Casseroles, Mac& Cheese; pies, pasties, sausage rolls, pirozhki, ... grill some cheesesteak on a metal plate? Options are endless!
